description: An overview of the scientific foundations of nutrition. The focus is on the functions, food sources and metabolism of carbohydrate,fat, protein, vitamins and minerals. Effects of deficiency and excess are discussed and dietary recommendations for disease prevention are emphasized. Current issues and controversies are highlighted. Students will analyze their own dietary intakes and develop plans for future actions.
name: NUTRITION: SCIENCE & APPLICATIONS

values.comments:
Nursing 112 is an overview of the scientific foundations of nutrition. The focus is on the functions, food sources and metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins and minerals. Effects of deficiency and excess are discussed and dietary recommendations for disease prevention are emphasized. Current issues and controversies are highlighted. Students will analyze their own dietary intakes and develop plans for future actions in a final project.

Students, in general, thought that this was a “great course.” They found it “informative” and “practical,” while simultaneously “simple and straightforward.” Some students felt that the course “changed [their] perspective” on their diets and that which they would suggest to patients. Many found the final project “helpful.”

Students very much appreciated Professor Hayes. Although some were apprehensive about maintaining interest during a three-hour course, they found that Professor Hayes did an “amazing job at communicating the course material and keeping students interested.” The instructors, to which some students referred by first name, were “very open about what they expect from their students” and “legitimately want the class to do well.”

Students reported having three exams and one final project during the class. The tests were reported to be straightforward and the course, overall, was “not tricky.” Some felt, though, that the readings were not well incorporated into the class and that they seemed like a waste of time. Some students reported that the exam material was drawn, in large part, from lecture notes. Some recommended for the class for all students with “little to no background in nutrition.”
